rev.comment: /* 1 February â March of the Millions */
rev.diff:
Line 182: Line 182:
Similar protests occurred across Egypt with hundreds of thousands protesting in Alexandria, and an estimated 250,000 protesting in Sinai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112113115442982.html|title=Protesters Flood Egypt Streets|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/01/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests – Live Updates|work=The Guardian |location=UK}}</ref> and [[Suez]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/02/stories/2011020263100100.htm |title=Front Page : Unprecedented show of people power at Egypt's Tahrir Square |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> marking the largest mobilisation in the then eight day old protest. Meanwhile, a virtual "March of Millions" was launched on Facebook with the goal of reaching one million voices in support of the march.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=126197157451259|title=Niet compatibele browser|publisher=Facebook|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Similar protests occurred across Egypt with hundreds of thousands protesting in Alexandria, and an estimated 250,000 protesting in Sinai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112113115442982.html|title=Protesters Flood Egypt Streets|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/01/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests – Live Updates|work=The Guardian |location=UK}}</ref> and [[Suez]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/02/stories/2011020263100100.htm |title=Front Page : Unprecedented show of people power at Egypt's Tahrir Square |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> marking the largest mobilisation in the then eight day old protest. Meanwhile, a virtual "March of Millions" was launched on Facebook with the goal of reaching one million voices in support of the march.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=126197157451259|title=Niet compatibele browser|publisher=Facebook|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|work=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister weighs in on the crisis|publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|work=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister weighs in on the crisis|publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
